localizedDescriptions.en: A persistent and managed list of any combination of archetypes that will support the accurate recording of a Care plan.
Contacts for patients and organisations (excluding practitioners).
The relationship between the subject and the contact. This field is only appropriate when the archetype is used for patient contacts, not for organisation contacts.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is desirable where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Indicates a purpose for which the contact can be reached. This field is only appropriate when the archetype is used inside an organisation cluster.
Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party.
Type of name described.

localizedDescriptions.en: Name in free text unstructured format.
Name in structured format.
The prefix or title used by the subject.

annotations.comment: e.g. 'Mr', 'Mrs', 'Ms', 'Dr', 'Lord'

localizedDescriptions.en: Given / personal / first name.
Middle name or names.
Family name or Surname.
Additional term used following a person name.

annotations.comment: e.g. 'Snr'

localizedDescriptions.en: FHIR telecom details.
Telecommunications form for contact point - what communications system is required to make use of the contact.
The communication form is phone.
The communication form is fax.
The communication form is email.
The communication form is URL.
The communication form is pager.
The communication is SMS.
The communication form is other.
The actual contact point details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address).
The purpose of the contact point.
Home contact details.
Work contact details.
Temporary contact details.
Old contact details.
Mobile contact details.
Specifies a preferred order in which to use a set of contacts. Contacts are ranked with lower values coming before higher values.
Details about the location of a person, physical building or landmark.
An unstructured address line representing all relevant street-level or post-box details that would support the identification of a location.

annotations.comment: Occurrences for this data element is set to 0..* to allow one or more free text 'Address line' data elements to represent the huge variety of ways that ‘street-level' details may need to be recorded within the context of a specified 'Town'. Multiple address lines can be represented in a template, renamed as 'Address line 1', 'Address line 2,' etc. For example: '7A/52 Davis Street' or 'Apartment 7A' as Address line 1 with '52 Davis Street' as Address line 2; a roadside mail box location, such as 'RMB 725, Princes Highway'; or using a descriptive landmark, such as or 'Corner of Smith & Brown Streets' or 'Second house north of the general store with the red door'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The name of the lowest level locality that contains the address.

annotations.comment: For example: suburb, town, city, settlement, village, or community. Coding with an external terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: 'Fitzroy'; 'Manchester'; 'Kingston' or 'Bergen'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The name of a local government district or geographical area that contains the address.

annotations.comment: Coding with an external terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: 'Surf Coast' and 'Yarra' local government councils in Victoria, Australia;and the Parishes of 'Saint Andrew' and 'Kingston' in Jamaica..

localizedDescriptions.en: The name of a major government district or geographical area that contains the address.

annotations.comment: Coding with an external terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: 'New South Wales' and 'Queensland' in Australia; 'British Columbia' and 'Nova Scotia' in Canada; and the Counties of 'Cornwall', 'Middlesex' & 'Surrey' in Jamaica.

localizedDescriptions.en: The code for a postal delivery area containing the address, as defined by the relevant postal delivery service.

annotations.comment: Also known as a postcode or ZIP code.

localizedDescriptions.en: The name of the country containing the address.

annotations.comment: For example: Australia; Canada; Jamaica; or Norway. Coding with an external terminology, such as EN ISO 3166–1 Alpha 2 country code, is recommended.

localizedDescriptions.en: The type of address.

annotations.comment: For example: physical or postal.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the address not captured in other fields.
Contacts for patients and organisations (excluding practitioners).
The relationship between the subject and the contact. This field is only appropriate when the archetype is used for patient contacts, not for organisation contacts.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is desirable where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Indicates a purpose for which the contact can be reached. This field is only appropriate when the archetype is used inside an organisation cluster.
Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party.
Type of name described.

Care team details aligned with FHIR resource.
Identifier details aligned with FHIR resources or data types.
The identifier value.
The current state of the care team.
The current status of the care team is proposed.
The current status of the care team is active.
The current status of the care team is suspended.
The current status of the care team is inactive.
The current status of the care team is entered in error.
Identifies what kind of team. This is to support differentiation between multiple co-existing teams, such as care plan team, episode of care team, longitudinal care team.
The care team category is event.
The care team category is encounter.
The care team category is episode.
The care team category is longitudinal.
The care team category is condition.
The care team category is clinicial research.
A label for human use intended to distinguish like teams.

annotations.comment: E.g. the "red" vs. "green" trauma teams.

localizedDescriptions.en: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.

The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing. The start may be in the past, and the end date in the future, which means that period is expected/planned to end at that time.
Identifies all people and organizations who are expected to be involved in the care team.
Indicates specific responsibility of an individual within the care team, such as "Primary care physician", "Trained social worker counselor", "Caregiver", etc.
Practitioner details aligned with FHIR resource.
Whether this practitioner's record is in active use.
Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party.
Type of name described.

list.label: Geslachtsnaam partner gevolgd door eigen geslachtsnaam

The prefix or title used by the subject.

annotations.comment: e.g. 'Mr', 'Mrs', 'Ms', 'Dr', 'Lord'

The communication form is phone.

An unstructured address line representing all relevant street-level or post-box details that would support the identification of a location.

Multiple address lines can be represented in a template, renamed as 'Address line 1', 'Address line 2,' etc. For example: '7A/52 Davis Street' or 'Apartment 7A' as Address line 1 with '52 Davis Street' as Address line 2; a roadside mail box location, such as 'RMB 725, Princes Highway'; or using a descriptive landmark, such as or 'Corner of Smith & Brown Streets' or 'Second house north of the general store with the red door'.

annotations.comment: For example: physical or postal.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the address not captured in other fields.
Administrative Gender - the gender that the person is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.
The practitioner gender is male.
The practitioner gender is female.
The practitioner gender is other.
The practitioner gender is unknown.
Practitioner role details aligned with FHIR resource.
Roles which this practitioner may perform.
Specific specialty or specialties of the practitioner.
The location(s) at which this practitioner provides care.
The list of healthcare services that this worker provides for this role's Organization/Location(s).
The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.

The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing. The start may be in the past, and the end date in the future, which means that period is expected/planned to end at that time.
Comments made about the participant.
Describes why the care team exists.
An entity comprising one or more people and having a particular purpose.

annotations.comment: For example: a company, institution, association, network, department, community group, healthcare practice group, payer/insurer, care team, or a group of neighbours who provide care or support.

localizedDescriptions.en: The unstructured name or label for the organisation.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Royal Children's Hospital'; 'ABC District Nursing Service'; 'YNWA Oslo' or 'JB Smith Lawyers'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identifier associated with the organisation.

annotations.comment: Occurrences for this data element is set to 0..* to allow for more than one Identifier to be recorded. Note that the ID data type contains multiple subcomponents for recording the ID value, type, issuer and assigner.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identifier associated with the organisation.
Identifier associated with the organisation.
The relationship or role of the organisation to the individual or subject of care.

annotations.comment: For example: oncologist; palliative care home nursing service; or informal support network.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the organisation not captured in other fields.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Details about a single identified health condition, injury, disability or any other issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual.

annotations.comment: Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation with this archetype, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing levels of detail and supportive evidence usually providing weight towards the label of 'diagnosis'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.

annotations.comment: Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Specific variant or subtype of the Diagnosis, if relevant.

annotations.comment: For example: 'acute motor axonal neuropathy' as a variant of Guillain-Barre Syndrome. Coding of the name of the variant with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about the problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment: Use to provide background and context, including evolution, episodes or exacerbations, progress and any other relevant details, about the problem or diagnosis.

localizedDescriptions.en: A physical site on or within the human body.
Identification of a single physical site either on, or within, the human body.

annotations.comment:
This data element is the only mandated data point in this archetype and should be used as the primary data point to record an anatomical location with a commonly used name. It is strongly recommended that 'Body site name' be recorded as specifically as is anatomically possible. For example: record 'upper eyelid' rather than recording 'eyelid' with 'upper' as a qualifier; 'fifth rib' rather than 'rib' with a numeric qualifier. Use the other data elements for laterality, aspect, region and anatomical line to provide more detail.

This data element should be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible - an appropriate termset for use here could comprise individual concepts or a list of precoordinated terms. Free text should be used only if there is no appropriate terminology available.

If body site name is already identified in the parent archetype, then this data element may be redundant. Alternatively, a use case has been identified where the value may be duplicated into this element to support semantic querying using this archetype, rather than the data element within the parent.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional detail using a specific region or a point on, or within, the identified body site.

annotations.comment: Use to increase precision of identification of the body site, if required. For example, the upper right quadrant or McBurney's point on the abdominal wall or interphalangeal joint of the great toe. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include the specific site, then this data element is redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: The side of the body on which the identified  body site is located.

annotations.comment:
If the identified body site has no laterality, this data element should not have a value. 
If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include laterality, then this data element is redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: Left side of the body.
Right side of the body.
Qualifying detail about the specific aspect of the identified body site.

annotations.comment: Use to increase precision of identification of the body site, if required. Common aspects have been included as a value set, which can be extended over time, plus a free text option. Assumes that the body is being described while in the anatomical position. For example: proximal urethra; plantar aspect of the left thumb. Multiple aspects can also be described, if required, by allowing for 0..2 occurrences. For example: a lesion may be on the left anterior/lateral (ie anterolateral) chest wall. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include the aspect, then this data element is redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: Towards the midline of the body site.
Towards the side, or edge, of the body site.
Above the body site, often meaning towards the head.
Below the body site, often meaning towards the feet.
Towards the front, or ventral surface, of  the body site.
Towards the back, or dorsal surface, of the body site.
More central or closer to the point of attachment, and usually describing part of a limb, digit or appendage.
More peripheral, or further from the point of attachment, and usually describing part of a limb, digit or appendage.
Away from the surface of the body site.
Towards the surface of the body site.
Towards the palm of the hand.
Towards the sole of the foot.
Towards the back of the hand or top of the foot. To be used as opposites of palmar or plantar, not as a synonym of posterior.
In the middle of the body site.
Towards the mouth. Usually used to describe locations within the digestive system.
Towards the anus. Usually used to describe locations within the digestive system.
Additional detail using theoretical lines drawn through anatomical structures used to provide a consistent reference point on the human body.

annotations.comment: Common anatomical lines have been included as a value set, which can be extended over time, plus a free text option. The additional use of this data element allows for recording of the typical position of the heart's apex beat at 5th intercostal space, left side, and mid-clavicular line. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include anatomical line, then this data element is redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: Line running vertically which divides the body into left and right portions, passing through the head, spinal cord, and umbilicus. Alternatively it can refer to a line dividing a body part into two equal portions, for example a digit.
Line running vertically down the surface of the body, passing through the apex of the axilla.
Line running vertically down the surface of the body, passing through the anterior axillary skinfold.
Line running vertically down the surface of the body, passing through the posterior axillary skinfold.
Line running vertically down the surface of the body, parallel to the midline and passing through the midpoint of the clavicle.
Line running vertically down the face through the midpoint of the pupil when looking directly forward.
Line running vertically down the posterior surface of the body, parallel to the midline and passing through the inferior point of the scapula.
Narrative description that can be used to further refine and support the 'Body site name'.

annotations.comment: For example: adjacent to the vermilion border; a tattoo covers the bottom half of this area.

localizedDescriptions.en: A cause, set of causes, or manner of causation of the problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment: Also known as 'aetiology' or 'etiology'. Coding with an external terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Estimated or actual date/time that signs or symptoms of the problem/diagnosis were first observed.

annotations.comment: Data captured/imported as "Age at onset" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.

localizedDescriptions.en: Estimated or actual date/time the diagnosis or problem was recognised by a healthcare professional.

annotations.comment: Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of clinical recognition" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.

localizedDescriptions.en: Estimated or actual date/time of resolution or remission for this problem or diagnosis, as determined by a healthcare professional.

annotations.comment: Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of resolution" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.

localizedDescriptions.en: Contextual or temporal qualifier for a specified problem or diagnosis.
Stage or phase of diagnostic process.

annotations.comment:
The status is usually determined by a combination of the timing of diagnosis plus level of clinical certainty resulting from diagnostic tests and clinical evidence available. This data element and 'Diagnostic certainty' in EVALUATION.problem_diagnosis are two important axes of the diagnostic process, and valid combinations will need to be presented by software that exposes both data elements, so it is not possible for users to select conflicting combinations. 
Preliminary or working diagnoses are intended to represent the single most likely choice out of all differential diagnosis options.

localizedDescriptions.en: The initial diagnosis made, usually associated with a low level of clinical certainty. It may change as test results or advice become available.
Interim diagnosis, based on a reasonable amount of clinical certainty but pending further test results or clinical advice. It may still change as test results or advice become available.
Final substantiated diagnosis, based on a high level of clinical certainty, which may include clinical evidence from test results. It is not expected to change.
The previously recorded diagnosis has been clinically reassessed or disproved with a high level of clinical certainty. This status is used to correct an error in the health record.
Category that supports division of problems and diagnoses into Current or Past problem lists.

annotations.comment: The Current/Past and Active/Inactive data elements have similar clinical impact but represent slightly different semantics. Both are actively used in different clinical settings, but usually not together. If an Active/Inactive qualifier is recorded, then this data element is likely to be redundant. An exception where a condition can be current but inactive is asthma that is not causing acute symptoms.

localizedDescriptions.en: An issue occuring at present.
An issue which ocurred in the past.
Category that supports division of problems and diagnoses into Active or Inactive problem lists.

annotations.comment: The Active/Inactive and Current/Past data elements have similar clinical impact but represent slightly different semantics. Both are actively used in different clinical settings, but usually not together. If a Current/Past qualifier is recorded, then this data element is likely to be redundant. An exception where a condition can be current but inactive is asthma that is not causing acute symptoms.

localizedDescriptions.en: The problem or diagnosis is currently active and clinically relevant.
The problem or diagnosis is not completely resolved but is inactive or felt less relevant to the current clinical context.
Category of the level of control of the problem or diagnosis by the current management.
The problem or diagnosis is controlled by current management.
It is not possible to determine if the problem or diagnosis is controlled by current management.
The problem or diagnosis is not controlled by current management.
Category of the progression through the course of a chronic problem or diagnosis.
The problem or diagnosis is improving.
The problem or diagnosis is unchanged.
The problem or diagnosis is worsening.
It is not possible to determine the progression of the problem or diagnosis.
Phase of healing for an acute problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment: For example: tracking the progress of resolution of a middle ear infection.

localizedDescriptions.en: Problem or diagnosis is not progressing satisfactorily through the normal stages of restoration or healing towards resolution.
Problem or diagnosis is progressing satisfactorily through the normal stages of restoration or healing towards resolution.
Problem or diagnosis has completed the normal phases of restoration or healing and can be considered resolved.
It is not possible to determine the resolution or healing status of the problem or diagnosis.
Problem or diagnosis has deteriorated after a period of temporary improvement.
Status of the remission of an incurable diagnosis.

annotations.comment: For example: the status of a cancer or haematological diagnosis.

localizedDescriptions.en: No ongoing signs or symptoms of the disease have been identified.
No diminution of the signs or symptoms of the disease have been identified.
It is not possible to determine if there have been diminution of the signs or symptoms of the disease have been identified.
Category of this episode for the identified problem/diagnosis.

annotations.comment: For example: 'New' will enable clinicians to distinguish a new, acute episode of otitis media that may have arisen soon after a previous diagnosis, to distinguish it from an unresolved or 'Ongoing' diagnosis of chronic otitis media. Treatment of recurring, new and acute, episodes of a condition may differ significantly from the same condition that is not resolving or responding to treatment. In many situations the clinician will not be able to tell, and so indeterminate may be appropriate.

localizedDescriptions.en: A new occurrence of either a new or existing problem or diagnosis. A flag for 'First occurrence' can be recorded separately to distinguish the first from other occurrences.
The issue, problem or diagnosis continues, without new, acute episodes occurring.
It is not possible to determine if this occurrence of the problem or diagnosis is new or ongoing.
Category of the problem or diagnosis within a specified episode of care and/or local care context.

annotations.comment:
This data element contains a value set commonly used in diagnostic categorisation. In episodic care contexts (commonly secondary care) it is common to categorise/organise diagnoses according to their relationship to the principal diagnosis being addressed during that episode of care. These categories may also be used for clinical coding, reporting and billing purposes. In some countries the diagnostic category may be known as a DRG.
 In addition, the free text choice permits use of other local value sets, as required.

list.label: Symptoom gerapporteerd door patiënt of andere bron van voorgeschiedenis

localizedLabels.en: Symptoom gerapporteerd door patiënt of andere bron van voorgeschiedenis

list.label: Bevinding van functionele prestatie en activiteit

localizedLabels.en: Bevinding van functionele prestatie en activiteit

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the Problem/Diagnosis qualifier values, not captured in other fields.
The level of confidence in the identification of the diagnosis.

annotations.comment: If an alternative valueset is required, these values can be added to the DV_TEXT data type in a template.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the problem or diagnosis not captured in other fields.
The date this problem or diagnosis was last updated.

An instrument, apparatus, implant, material or similar, used in the provision of healthcare. In this context, a medical device includes a broad range of devices which act through a variety of physical, mechanical, thermal or similar means but specifically excludes devices which act through medicinal means such as pharmacological, metabolic or immunological methods.  The scope is inclusive of disposable devices as well as durable or persisting devices that require tracking, maintenance activities or regular calibration, recognising that each type of device has specific data recording requirements.
Identification of the medical device, preferably by a common name, a formal fully descriptive name or, if required, by class or category of device.

annotations.comment: This data element will capture the term, phrase or category used in clinical practice. For example: <brand name><machine> (XYZ Audiometer); <size> <brand name> <intravenous catheter> (14G Jelco IV catheter); or <brand name/type> <implant>. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible, although this may be local and depending on local supplies available.

localizedDescriptions.en: The category or kind of device.

annotations.comment:
Not applicable if a category is already recorded in 'Device name'.
 Example: if the 'Device' is named as a 'urinary catheter'; the 'Type' may be recorded as 'indwelling' or 'condom'.Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible. This may include use of GTIN or EAN numbers.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the medical device.
A numeric or alphanumeric string that is associated with this device within a given system.

annotations.comment: Often fixed to the device as a barcode.

localizedDescriptions.en: Name of manufacturer.
Date the device was manufactured.
Number assigned by the manufacturer which can be found on the device, and should be specific to each device., its label, or accompanying packaging.
The exact number assigned by the manufacturer, as it appears in the manufacturer's catalogue, device labeling, or accompanying packaging.
The exact model number assigned by the manufacturer and found on the device label or accompanying packaging.
The number assigned by the manufacturer which identifies a group of items manufactured at the same time, usually found on the label or packaging material.
Identification of the version of software being used in the medical device.

annotations.comment: When the medical device is an actual software application, record the version of the software using this data element. When the medical device has multiple software applications embedded within it, record each software component in a separate CLUSTER archetype within the Components SLOT - either as a nested instance of another CLUSTER.device archetype or using a CLUSTER archetype designed specifically for recording software details (but not yet available at time of this archetype development).

localizedDescriptions.en: Date after which the device/product is no longer fit for use, usually found on the device itself or printed on the accompanying packaging.

annotations.comment: This date usually applies only to single use or disposable devices.

localizedDescriptions.en: Unspecified identifier, which can be further specified in a template or at run time.

annotations.comment: Coding of the name of the identifier with a coding system is desirable, if available.

localizedDescriptions.en: Practitioner details aligned with FHIR resource.
Whether this practitioner's record is in active use.
Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party.
Type of name described.

list.label: Geslachtsnaam partner gevolgd door eigen geslachtsnaam

localizedLabels.en: Geslachtsnaam partner gevolgd door eigen geslachtsnaam

list.label: Eigen geslachtsnaam gevolgd door geslachtsnaam partner

localizedLabels.en: Eigen geslachtsnaam gevolgd door geslachtsnaam partner

localizedDescriptions.en: Name in free text unstructured format.
Name in structured format.
The prefix or title used by the subject.

annotations.comment: e.g. 'Mr', 'Mrs', 'Ms', 'Dr', 'Lord'

localizedDescriptions.en: Given / personal / first name.
Middle name or names.
Family name or Surname.
Additional term used following a person name.

annotations.comment: e.g. 'Snr'

localizedDescriptions.en: FHIR telecom details.
Telecommunications form for contact point - what communications system is required to make use of the contact.
The communication form is phone.
The communication form is fax.
The communication form is email.
The communication form is URL.
The communication form is pager.
The communication is SMS.
The communication form is other.
The actual contact point details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address).
The purpose of the contact point.
Home contact details.
Work contact details.
Temporary contact details.
Old contact details.
Mobile contact details.
Details about the location of a person, physical building or landmark.
An unstructured address line representing all relevant street-level or post-box details that would support the identification of a location.

annotations.comment: Occurrences for this data element is set to 0..* to allow one or more free text 'Address line' data elements to represent the huge variety of ways that ‘street-level' details may need to be recorded within the context of a specified 'Town'. Multiple address lines can be represented in a template, renamed as 'Address line 1', 'Address line 2,' etc. For example: '7A/52 Davis Street' or 'Apartment 7A' as Address line 1 with '52 Davis Street' as Address line 2; a roadside mail box location, such as 'RMB 725, Princes Highway'; or using a descriptive landmark, such as or 'Corner of Smith & Brown Streets' or 'Second house north of the general store with the red door'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The name of the lowest level locality that contains the address.

annotations.comment: For example: suburb, town, city, settlement, village, or community. Coding with an external terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: 'Fitzroy'; 'Manchester'; 'Kingston' or 'Bergen'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The name of a local government district or geographical area that contains the address.

annotations.comment: Coding with an external terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: 'Surf Coast' and 'Yarra' local government councils in Victoria, Australia;and the Parishes of 'Saint Andrew' and 'Kingston' in Jamaica..

localizedDescriptions.en: The name of a major government district or geographical area that contains the address.

annotations.comment: Coding with an external terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: 'New South Wales' and 'Queensland' in Australia; 'British Columbia' and 'Nova Scotia' in Canada; and the Counties of 'Cornwall', 'Middlesex' & 'Surrey' in Jamaica.

localizedDescriptions.en: The code for a postal delivery area containing the address, as defined by the relevant postal delivery service.

annotations.comment: Also known as a postcode or ZIP code.

localizedDescriptions.en: The name of the country containing the address.

annotations.comment: For example: Australia; Canada; Jamaica; or Norway. Coding with an external terminology, such as EN ISO 3166–1 Alpha 2 country code, is recommended.

localizedDescriptions.en: The type of address.

annotations.comment: For example: physical or postal.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the address not captured in other fields.
Administrative Gender - the gender that the person is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.
The practitioner gender is male.
The practitioner gender is female.
The practitioner gender is other.
The practitioner gender is unknown.
Practitioner role details aligned with FHIR resource.
Roles which this practitioner may perform.
Specific specialty or specialties of the practitioner.
The location(s) at which this practitioner provides care.
The list of healthcare services that this worker provides for this role's Organization/Location(s).
Additional narrative about the device not captured in other fields.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
A desired health, or well-being, outcome for the subject of care.
The name of the desired health outcome.

annotations.comment: For example: reduced blood pressure; 10 kilogram weight loss; or diabetes control.

localizedDescriptions.en: A narrative description of the goal, including target/s to be achieved if relevant.
Name of the problem or diagnosis which is intended to be impacted by achievement of this goal.

annotations.comment: For example: Hypertension; Obesity; or Diabetes Type 2.

localizedDescriptions.en: The anticipated or proposed date for commencing work towards the goal.

annotations.comment: Note: this date may not be the date of recording of the goal.

localizedDescriptions.en: The desired or proposed date for achieving the goal.
The actual date that the goal was achieved or abandoned.
Single word, phrase or brief description which represents the outcome actually achieved for the goal.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: target weight achieved; poor diabetes control; or successful completion.

localizedDescriptions.en: The proposed goal was realised.
The proposed goal was partially realised.
The proposed goal was not realised and abandoned.
Additional narrative about the goal not captured in other fields.

annotations.comment: For example: the reason why the goal was not achieved, or a description about how the goal was partially achieved.

localizedDescriptions.en: Detail about the intended target.

annotations.comment: Multiple targets are allowed. In some situations, only one target will be required. In some clinical scenarios the goal may require a multifaceted approach with a number of targets contributing to a successful goal outcome. In addition, some goals may require incremental targets to be set sequentially during a period of time.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the intended target, by name.

annotations.comment: For example: systolic blood pressure under 140 mmHg; lose 10 kilograms; or HBA1c in the normal range.

localizedDescriptions.en: The intended target.
The intended target.
The intended target.
The intended target.
The intended target.
The intended target.
The intended target.
The intended target.
Narrative description about the intended target.
The archetype and path to the node for target data.

annotations.comment: For example: the 'Weight' data element in the OBSERVATION.body_weight archetype.

localizedDescriptions.en: The desired or proposed date for achieving the target.
The actual date that the target was achieved or abandoned.
Single word, phrase or brief description which represents the outcome actually achieved for the target.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible. This data element could represent success or failure, or some state in between when the goal is completed or abandoned/removed from the record. For example: poor blood sugar control, or successful completion.

localizedDescriptions.en: The target was realised.
The target was partially realised.
The target was not realised and abandoned.
Additional narrative about the target not captured in other fields.

annotations.comment: For example: the reason why the target was not achieved, or a description about how the target was partially achieved.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date on which the goal was last updated.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
A framework to communicate the preferences of an individual for future medical treatment and care.
The type of advance care directive.

annotations.comment:
A short text description of the nature of the advance care directive. Coding of the type of directive with a terminology is preferred, where possible. It is expected that this is largely localised to reflect local policy and legislation.

For example, in the Netherlands, advance care directive types include, but are not limited to, 'Treatment prohibition', 'Treatment prohibition with completion of Completed Life', 'Euthanasia request' and 'Declaration of life'.

In the UK, advance care directive types include 'Advance Decision', 'Advance Directive' and 'Advance Statement'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The status of the advance care directive.

annotations.comment: Coding of the advance care directive status with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall advance care directive.

annotations.comment: May be used to record a narrative overview of the complete advance care directive, which may or may not be supported by structured data. Details of specific structured findings can be included using CLUSTER archetypes in the 'Directive details' slot. This data element may be used to capture legacy data that is not available in a structured format.

localizedDescriptions.en:
The conditions or situations in which the individual wishes the advance care directive to apply.

{als toegestaan= Ja, maar met beperkingen (JA_MAAR)}

annotations.comment:
For example: dementia, brain injury, diseases of the central nervous system, and terminal illness. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

The advance care directive applies to all specified conditions if the individual can no longer make or communicate decisions about their medical treatment and is unlikely to regain the ability to make such decisions. Details of specific decisions that apply to different conditions or situations can be included using CLUSTER archetypes in the 'Directive details' slot.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the advance care directive not captured in other fields.
The date/time that marks the beginning of the valid period of time for this advance care directive.
The date/time that marks the conclusion of the valid period of time for this advance care directive.

annotations.comment: 'Valid period end' may often overlap with 'Review due date'. However, they may need to be recorded separately in circumstances where a document has an extended period of validity but requires an interim review. That may be due to changed personal circumstances/events or local policy.

localizedDescriptions.en: Information about the physical or digital location of the Advance care directive.
Physical or digital location of the Advance care directive.
Physical or digital location of the Advance care directive.
Physical or digital location of the Advance care directive.
Contacts for patients and organisations (excluding practitioners).
The relationship between the subject and the contact. This field is only appropriate when the archetype is used for patient contacts, not for organisation contacts.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is desirable where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Indicates a purpose for which the contact can be reached. This field is only appropriate when the archetype is used inside an organisation cluster.
Gender details for the contact.
The contact's gender is male.
The contact's gender is female.
The contact's gender is other.
The contact's gender is unknown.
Date and time when contact detail starts to be valid.
Date and time when contact detail stops being valid.
Organ donation preferences.
Statement whether the subject is on the NHS Organ Donor register.
Subject's preference regarding organ donation.
The subject has explicitly opted in to donate their organs.
The subject has explicitly opted out from organ donation.
The subject has not stated whether they wish to donate their organs or their preference is not known.
Statement whether the subject wishes to donate all organs.
Description of which organ or organs the subject wishes to donate.
The subject wishes to donate their kidneys.
The subject wishes to donate their heart.
The subject wishes to donate their liver.
The subject wishes to donate their pancreas.
The subject wishes to donate their small bowel.
The subject wishes to donate their lungs.
The subject wishes to donate their corneas.
The subject wishes to donate tissue.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Anticipatory decisions about the overall intent of care and possible interventions (including treatments, activities, and diagnostic or therapeutic procedures), asserted by a clinician.
The overall intent for future care and treatment for the individual.

annotations.comment:
The proposed value set is based on the MJA reference. 
Coding the intent of care with an external terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The condition is curable; all appropriate life-prolonging treatment will be offered.
The condition is treatable with potential for restoration to the previous state of health or a prolonged remission; all appropriate life-prolonging treatment will be offered.

The condition is incurable and progressive; active treatment of the underlying disease may be appropriate for specific symptom relief and/or short term life expectancy gains; focused on comfort, quality of life and dignity. Also referred to as 'Palliative'.
Life expectancy is short (hours or days); no active treatment of the underlying disease or treatment-related harm; focus on comfort, quality of life and dignity.
The intent of care decision is not known.
Narrative description about the logic and justification for the 'Intent of care' decision.
Narrative description about all advance intervention decisions, including the CPR decision.

annotations.comment: May be used to record a narrative overview of the advance intervention decision that reflect the specific circumstances for the individual. This includes any limitations, or conditional circumstances applicable, to interventions. This description may or may not be supported by structured data, recorded using the ‘Per intervention’ cluster. If both this narrative description and ‘Per intervention’ structured data is recorded, caution is required as there is a potential risk of divergence. This data element may be used to capture legacy data that is not available in a structured format.

localizedDescriptions.en: Decision about the extent of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) intervention appropriate for this individual.
All appropriate cardiopulmonary resuscitation treatments should be attempted to save or prolong life.
Cardiopulmonary resuscitation treatments should be attempted, as specified in the 'Decisions description' narrative or as structured data in the 'Per intervention' cluster.

No cardiopulmonary resuscitation treatments should be attempted to save or prolong life. Also known as 'Do not resuscitate (DNR)'; 'Do not attempt resuscitation (DNAR)'; 'Not for resuscitation (NFR)' or similar.
The CPR decision is not known.
Details of the decision about possible treatments or activities that may be life-saving, life-prolonging or cause undesirable side effects.
Name of the possible treatment, procedure or activity.

annotations.comment: While this archetype is intended for all clinical decisions about possible future interventions, the proposed DV_CODED_TEXT value set for the 'Intervention' data element is deliberately not intended to be exhaustive. Instead it has been designed to be inclusive of most of the common life-saving treatments within an emergency context. The alternate choice of the DV_TEXT option can be used to add a local value set or bind to an alternative external value set within a template.

localizedDescriptions.en: Technique used to manually pump blood around the body during a cardiac arrest.
Use of electric shock to reset the electrical state of the heart.
Placement of a tube into the trachea to maintain an open airway, including a tracheostomy.
Artificial ventilation where invasive means are used to assist or replace spontaneous breathing.
Artificial ventilation where non-invasive means are used to assist or replace spontaneous breathing.
Insertion of a peripheral intravenous line.

list.label: Central venous line or any arterial line

localizedLabels.en: Central venous line or any arterial line

localizedDescriptions.en: Insertion of a central venous line or any arterial line.
Maintenance of hydration by means other than eating or drinking.
Provision of nutrients by means other than eating or drinking.
Medications used during an emergency resuscitation to prolong life. For example: adrenaline, atropine, sodium bicarbonate, calcium, other vasoactive medications.
Medication that supports heart function, including but not limited to: vasopressors, inotropes and chronotropes.
Medications to treat infections.
Therapeutic substance prepared from human blood including, but not limited to: whole blood; blood components; and plasma derivatives.
Insertion of a tube into the pleural space.
Insertion of an artificial pacemaker to control the heart beat.
Process of removing excess water, solutes, and toxins from the blood.
Transfer to hospital for assessment or admission.
Transfer and admission to an intensive care or high dependency unit.
Decision about the identified intervention.
The intervention is recommended.
The intervention is recommended only in specific circumstances, captured using the 'Preconditions' data element.
The intervention is not recommended.
The intervention decision is not known.
Description of the circumstance/s in which a 'Conditional recommendation' is applicable.

annotations.comment: This data element is only relevant if the 'Conditional recommendation' option is selected in the 'Decision' data element. For example:' "Transfer to hospital is only applicable in the circumstances where the individual suffers a fracture and requires immobilization for pain relief.#

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the intervention decision, not captured in other fields.

annotations.comment: For example: the justification or rationale for the intervention decision.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about awareness of the Advance intervention decisions by the individual.

annotations.comment: For example: the capacity of the patient to understand the decisions.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about awareness of the Advance intervention decisions by family, carers or legal proxy.

annotations.comment: For example: the individual has no family.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about all advance intervention decisions, not captured in other fields.
The date and/or time when the Advance intervention decisions were last updated.
The date/time that marks the beginning of the valid period of time for the Advance intervention decisions.
The date/time that marks the conclusion of the valid period of time for the Advance intervention decisions.

annotations.comment: 'Valid period end' may often overlap with 'Review due date'. However, they may need to be recorded separately in circumstances where a document has an extended period of validity but requires an interim review. That may be due to changed personal circumstances/events or local policy.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date when review of the Advance intervention decisions are due.
Information about the physical or digital location of the advance intervention decisions record.
Physical or digital location of the Advance intervention decisions record.
Physical or digital location of the Advance intervention decisions record.
Physical or digital location of the Advance intervention decisions record.

The advance recommendation as to whether cardio-pulmonary resuscitation should be undertaken or not. This is generally referred to in UK clinical guidance as the CPR (Cardio-pulmonary resuscitation) decision.
The advance recommendation as to whether cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) should be attempted. In some cases a clear answer may not be available to the recording clinician.

list.label: CPR attempts recommended adult or child

localizedLabels.en: CPR attempts recommended adult or child

localizedDescriptions.en: Cardio-pulmonary resuscitation is recommended for adult or child.

list.label: CPR attempts not recommended adult or child.

localizedLabels.en: CPR attempts not recommended adult or child.

localizedDescriptions.en: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is not recommended for adult or child.
There is no clear information on the outcome of the CPR decision.
Modified CPR is recommended for child only.
The date at which the CPR decision was originally taken or last reviewed.

children.name: Details for Modified CPR child only
children.localizedName: Details for Modified CPR child only

localizedNames.en: Details for Modified CPR child only

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of modification where modified CPR for child only has been selected.
Is the patient aware of the CPR decision?

list.label: Patient not aware of CPR decision

localizedLabels.en: Patient not aware of CPR decision

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient is not aware of the cardiopulmonary resuscitation decision.
The patient is aware of the cardiopulmonary resucitation decision.
Is the informal carer, or carers, aware of the CPR decision?

list.label: Informal carer not aware of CPR decision

localizedLabels.en: Informal carer not aware of CPR decision

localizedDescriptions.en: The informal carer is not aware of the do not attempt cardiopulmonary resuscitation clinical decision.

list.label: Informal carer aware of CPR decision

localizedLabels.en: Informal carer aware of CPR decision

localizedDescriptions.en: The informal carer is aware of the do not attempt cardiopulmonary resucitation decision.
Other narrative comment pertinent to the CPR decision.
Has the physical CPR form been completed?
The physical CPR form has been completed.
The physical CPR form has not been completed.
The completion status of the CPR form is not known.
Has resuscitation been discussed with  the patient?
Resuscitation has been discussed with the patient.
Resuscitation has not been discussed with the patient.
Has resuscitation been discussed with  the patient's informal carer or carers?
Resuscitation has been discussed with the patient's informal carer.

list.label: Resuscitation not discussed with informal carer

localizedLabels.en: Resuscitation not discussed with informal carer

localizedDescriptions.en: Resuscitation has not been discussed with the patient's informal carer or carers.
The location of the original CPR document, either a text description or an electronic link.
The location of the original CPR document, either a text description or an electronic link.
The location of the original CPR document, either a text description or an electronic link.

children.name: Date for review of CPR decision
children.localizedName: Date for review of CPR decision

localizedNames.en: Date for review of CPR decision

localizedDescriptions.en: The date at which the CPR decision should be reviewed.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
The subject's preferred priorities of care and 'What matters'.
A narrative statement by the patient on their preferred priorities of care.

annotations.comment: In the UI, this should be represented as 'Considering the above priorities. what is most important to you? (optional)'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Any other specifc personal request or preference, including cultural or religious preferences.
The patient's preferred place of care (first choice).
The patient's preferred place of care is at home.
The patient's preferred place of care is a hospice.

list.label: Preferred place of care - community hospital

localizedLabels.en: Preferred place of care - community hospital

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient's preferred place of care is a community hospital.
The patient's preferred place of care is a  hospital.

list.label: Preferred place of care - nursing home

localizedLabels.en: Preferred place of care - nursing home

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient's preferred place of care is a nursing home.

list.label: Preferred place of care - residential home

localizedLabels.en: Preferred place of care - residential home

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient's preferred place of care is a residential home.

list.label: Preferred place of care - patient declined to participate

localizedLabels.en: Preferred place of care - patient declined to participate

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient has declined to offer a preferred place of care.

list.label: Preferred place of care - discussion not appropriate

localizedLabels.en: Preferred place of care - discussion not appropriate

localizedDescriptions.en: Discussion of preferred place of care is inappropriate.

list.label: Preferred place of care - patient unable to express preference

localizedLabels.en: Preferred place of care - patient unable to express preference

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient has been unable to express preference about place of care.
The patient's preferred place of care (second choice).
The patient's preferred place of care is at home.
The patient's preferred place of care is a hospice.

list.label: Preferred place of care - community hospital

localizedLabels.en: Preferred place of care - community hospital

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient's preferred place of care is a community hospital.
The patient's preferred place of care is a  hospital.

list.label: Preferred place of care - nursing home

localizedLabels.en: Preferred place of care - nursing home

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient's preferred place of care is a nursing home.

list.label: Preferred place of care - residential home

localizedLabels.en: Preferred place of care - residential home

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient's preferred place of care is a residential home.

list.label: Preferred place of care - patient declined to participate

localizedLabels.en: Preferred place of care - patient declined to participate

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient has declined to offer a preferred place of care.

list.label: Preferred place of care - discussion not appropriate

localizedLabels.en: Preferred place of care - discussion not appropriate

list.label: Preferred place of care - patient unable to express preference

Details of the organisation/location of the preferred place of care.

children.name: Preferred place of care (second choice) location details
children.localizedName: Preferred place of care (second choice) location details

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient's first choice preferred place of death.
The patient's preferred place of death is at home.
The patient's preferred place of death is in a hospice.

list.label: Preferred place of death: community hospital

localizedLabels.en: Preferred place of death: community hospital

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient's preferred place of death is in a community hospital.
The patient's preferred place of death is in a hospital.

list.label: Preferred place of death: nursing home

localizedLabels.en: Preferred place of death: nursing home

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient's preferred place of death is in a nursing home.

list.label: Preferred place of death: residential home

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient's preferred place of death is in a residential home.

list.label: Preferred place of death: patient unable to express preference

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient is unable to express a preferred pace of death.

list.label: Preferred place of death discussed with patient

list.label: Preferred place of death: discussion not appropriate

list.label: Preferred place of death: patient undecided

list.label: Preferred place of death: patient declined discussion

Indication on a scale of 1 - 100 of where priority for care should be. 1 indicates absolute priority on sustaining life (even at the expense of comfort) and 100 indicates absolute priority on comfort (even at the expense of sustaining life).
Any additional comments about the subject's place of care preferences.
The date that the preferences were first stated or last updated.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
